metadata.case_name: State of Maharashtra v. Respondent No. 1 (Defendant No. 7)

facts.text: Plaintiff-respondent No. 1 instituted Special Suit No. 5 of 1957 in the Court of the Civil Judge Senior Division at Ahmedabad to recover Rs.13,205 on account of the principal lent to defendant No. 7 and interest up to the date of the suit at the rate of 9% per annum.
On July 18, 1960, the suit was decreed in a sum of Rs. 13,033-6-6 with future interest from the date of suit till realization at 4% per annum on a sum of Rs. 10,120.
Defendant No. 7 appealed to the Bombay High Court against the decree. In the memorandum of appeal, valued the claim for purposes of jurisdiction and court-fee at Rs. 13,033-6-6.

Grounds of appeal: Ground No.1 - lower Court erred in decreeing the plaintiff's suit; Ground No.48 - decree is otherwise erroneous, unjust and illegal; remaining 46 grounds related to merits of plaintiff's claim, did not deal with correctness of trial Court awarding future pendente lite interest.

Taxing Officer held appeal was against the whole decree, subject-matter value Rs. 14,036.80nP. including interest from suit date till decree on Rs.10,120 (Rs.1,033.40nP.), directed deficit court-fee of Rs.70.

Defendant No.7 filed revision to Bombay High Court under s.52 of the Bombay Court-fees Act, 1959. Objection upheld by single Judge on April 12, 1961, who held subject-matter is real matter in dispute, right in dispute; set aside Taxing Officer's order.
State of Maharashtra filed appeal by special leave to Supreme Court against High Court order.

legal_issues.text: Whether the amount of interest decreed for the period subsequent to the institution of the suit comes within the expression 'amount or value of the subject-matter in dispute' in Art.1 of Schedule 1 of the Bombay Court-fees Act, 1959, for purposes of court-fee payable on the memorandum of appeal.

petitioner_arguments.text: View of High Court Judge is not correct; relies on construction by Courts on 'value or subject-matter in dispute' in provisions for High Courts giving leave to appeal to Privy Council, e.g., interest up to decree included (Gooroo Persad, Doorga Doss); costs not part of subject-matter.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Privy Council cases: Gooroo Persad Khoond v. Juggutchunder; Doorga Doss Chowdry v. Ramanauth Chowdry

respondent_arguments.text: Subject-matter in appeal is the real matter in dispute between the parties and not something which must stand or fall with the decision on it; it must mean the right which is in dispute between the parties.

court_reasoning.text: Act is taxing statute, provisions construed strictly in favour of subject-litigant; unlike liberal construction for Privy Council appeals. Defendant valued appeal at Rs.13,033-6-6, disputing principal and interest up to suit; did not dispute pendente lite interest, no grounds challenge it specifically.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Value determined by substantial allegations/pleas on points in dispute; pendente lite interest awarded in discretion u/s.34 CPC, no right to it unless specifically challenged.

court_reasoning.text: Well-settled: no court-fee on interest pendente lite unless specifically challenged (Mitthu Lal v. Chameli); same for costs and future interest post-decree; principle: value of right claimed, not discretionary awards.
court_reasoning.key_observation: If appellant succeeds on main claim, discretionary awards modified automatically; no need to appeal them unless expressly disputed.

court_reasoning.text: No good reason to distinguish costs from pendente lite interest; both discretionary, not asserted rights.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Grounds of appeal relate only to principal and pre-suit interest.

holdings.text: Amount of pendente lite interest decreed is not to be included in the amount or value of the subject-matter in dispute in appeal for purposes of Art.1 Schedule 1 of the Act unless appellant specifically challenges correctness of decree for pendente lite interest independently of claim to set aside decree.

precedents_cited.relevance: Interest decreed up to date of decree included in value for Privy Council appeal leave.

precedents_cited.case_name: Doorga Doss Chowdry v. Ramanauth Chowdry
precedents_cited.relevance: Costs of suit not part of subject-matter in dispute.
No court-fee on pendente lite interest unless specifically challenged; same as costs.
No court-fee on future interest from suit to appeal filing unless expressly challenged.
Costs not part of subject-matter; appellant succeeds on costs if succeeds on main matter.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Court-fees Act, 1959
statutes_cited.relevance: Court-fee on memo of appeal ad valorem on amount/value of subject-matter in dispute; revision against Taxing Officer.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Court's discretion to award pendente lite interest and costs.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court order upheld; memorandum of appeal sufficiently stamped as defendant did not specifically challenge pendente lite interest.
outcome.relief_granted: None to appellant; confirmation of High Court order in favour of respondent.

key_quotes.text: The Act is a taxing statute and its provisions therefore have to be construed strictly, in favour of the subject-litigant.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Principle of strict construction for court-fees.

key_quotes.text: Interest pendente lite is awarded under section 34 of the Civil Procedure Code. The Court may award it whether the plaintiff claims it or not.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: We therefore hold that the amount of pendente lite interest decreed is not to be included in the amount or value of the subject-matter in dispute in appeal for the purposes of art. 1 of Schedule 1 of the Act unless the appellant specifically challenges the correctness of the decree for the amount of interest pendente lite independently of the claim to set aside that decree.
key_quotes.speaker: court
